page.title: 03ECOLOGY ABINGTON MEADOW
page.content: The river Granta runs between Great and Little Abington. There are minnows, brook lampreys, stone loaches and brown trout. Also there are frogs and toads. There are lots of beautiful trees, especially the horse chestnuts. There is a row of trees and bushes which divides the meadow from the cricket pitch, made up of hawthorn, ash and elder with some dead elms. There are rabbits in the meadow and hedgehogs, moles, bank voles and bats. There are hornets, peacock butterflys, painted ladies, commas, orange tips, holly blues and tortoise- shells. Little owls breed in the meadow. There are also kingfishers, mallards, spotted flycatchers, jays, lesser spotted woodpeckers, house martins, swifts, swallows, coaltits, kestrels,blackcaps and longtailed tits
